item.title: That New Silent Hill 2 Movie Has A Horrific 7% On Rotten Tomatoes
item.content:encoded:
Return to Silent Hill, a live-action film adaptation of Konami‚Äôs beloved Silent Hill 2, hits theaters later this week. Early reviews for the horror flick are as scary as any monster from the games.

First announced in 2022, Return to Silent Hill releases on January 23. It isn‚Äôt connected to the past two Silent Hill movies, even though it was directed by the first film‚Äôs Christophe Gans, and is instead a loose adaptation of the PS2-era survival horror classic Silent Hill 2. Marketing for this film has been minimal to say the least, partially because it seems the executives involved realized it wasn‚Äôt great back when it wrapped filming in 2023, and the movie is only seeing the light of day after that recent Silent Hill 2 remake did so well. But after the delay and the lack of marketing, perhaps this is a very good horror film? Nope. Doesn‚Äôt seem like it.

As of January 21, there are 15 reviews for Return to Silent Hill on critic aggregator Rotten Tomatoes. And the new movie has an abysmal seven percent Tomatometer score. For those not familiar with Rotten Tomatoes, that ain‚Äôt a great score. In fact, if this seven percent score holds, Return to Silent Hill will go down as one of the worst-reviewed movies ever. Yikes.

The general consensus from critics is that while parts of Return to Silent Hill look great, the film is a boring, sloppy, confusing, and (perhaps worst of all for the genre) not-very-scary movie about a main character that is hard to relate to and who seems more confused than terrified.

‚ÄúThis powerful survival horror story has been turned into an ugly, laughable adaptation that proves that maybe we should‚Äôve never gone back to Silent Hill,‚Äù said Ross Bonaime over at Collider.

‚ÄúChristophe Gans‚Äôs film does away with all the psychosexual nuance of Silent Hill 2,‚Äù claims Justin Clark at Slant Magazine. 

‚ÄúI found the experience difficult to sit through and nonsensical from moment to moment, with its confounding story and shoddy CGI matched only by its lack of entertainment value,‚Äù said critic Brian Eggert.

At the moment, there is only one non-rotten score, from Dominic Baez at the Seattle Times, and it doesn‚Äôt read like a loving endorsement of the movie. Instead, it seems like Baez found most of the movie bad, but enjoyed the ending. The end credits are apparently very ‚Äústylish.‚Äù When critics are praising your credits and not much else, that‚Äôs a bad sign.

item.title: Video Game God Of War Congratulates Live Action God Of War
item.content:encoded:
Christopher Judge comments on his fellow Kratos. A new Kickstarter will transform your Switch 2 dock into an old-school GameCube. And two people who worked on Pirates of the Caribbean argue about what‚Äôs to blame for modern VFX looking dull and lifeless. It‚Äôs a very late edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news, rumors, and culture.

Who‚Äôs ready for more bad news for PC gaming? Samsung and SK Hynix are reportedly dropping NAND production to focus on DRAM. That could mean even more expensive SSDs. Bad timing for me to replace the PC I built back in 2015 with an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960.

Christopher Judge has weighed in on Ryan Hurst being Kratos in the Prime TV series

Christopher Judge reacts to Ryan Hurst being cast as Kratos in the live-action 'God of War' show ü™ì

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a magnificent choice. Great actor and a gamer who actually played God of War since its inception. So Kudos, you‚Äôve got a great live-action Kratos" pic.twitter.com/XFvPaMftH3

‚Äî Culture Crave üçø (@CultureCrave) January 21, 2026

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a magnificent choice,‚Äù the in-game performer for the titular character said this week. ‚ÄúGreat actor and a gamer who actually played God of War since its inception. So kudos, you‚Äôve got a great live-action Kratos.‚Äù The TV series also revealed that Max Parker will play the Watchman of Asgard, Heimdall.

Chris Pratt promises the Mario Galaxy movie still has more characters to reveal

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not allowed to say what they are, but yes, there are some really incredible‚Ä¶Well, I think some of them have been released in the trailer‚ÄìRosalina, Bowser Jr.‚Äìand then there‚Äôs even a couple more that are not in the trailer that people should be excited to see,‚Äù the star of Mercy told Gamesradar. Who could it be?

The maker of Payday 3 is laying off developers

Multiple staffers at Starbreeze Studios have been let go, Insider Gaming reports. ‚ÄúToday, many of us at Starbreeze, Stockholm, got sad news and I‚Äôm now seeking a new role and would appreciate your support,‚Äù wrote one of them on LinkedIn. ‚ÄúAfter over 7 years, the longest I‚Äôve ever been at any company in any industry, my time has (more than likely) come.‚Äù

No online multiplayer for Lego Batman: Legacy of the Dark Knight

Following in the footsteps of all the previous Lego games, the new Lego Batman won‚Äôt have online co-op. ‚ÄúFans of all generations will be able to enjoy the game solo or team up with a friend or family member through two-player local couch cooperative gameplay only,‚Äù reads the FAQ (via Prima Games).

Turn your Switch 2 into a GameCube

Battle Dock coming soon! pic.twitter.com/hRdu7zI6IV

‚Äî Retro Fighters (@retrofightersco) January 19, 2026

A new dock on Kickstarter promises to do exactly that. It‚Äôs going for $40 with a January ship date and attaches directly to your existing Switch 2 dock. It comes in various old-school GameCube colors like silver, indigo, and orange, and has connectors for up to four of the retro console‚Äôs controllers. Perfect for when Switch Online adds Mario Kart Double Dash and Smash Bros. Melee, if ever.

Yakuza Kiwami 3 & Dark Ties gets a free demo

It‚Äôs out today on PC and console, including Switch 2, and lets players experience a bit of the Ryukyu district in Okinawa as Kiryu and the series‚Äô familiar Kamurocho setting in Tokyo as Mine. The full remaster and all-new side story releases on all platforms on February 12.

Dueling Pirates of the Caribbean VFX takes

Director Gore Verbinksi talked to But Why Tho (via VGC) about the state of VFX. ‚ÄúSo it used to be a divide, with Unreal Engine being very good at video games, but then people started thinking maybe movies can also use Unreal for finished visual effects,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo you have this sort of gaming aesthetic entering the world of cinema.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúI think that Unreal Engine coming in and replacing Maya as a sort of fundamental is the greatest slip backwards.‚Äù

Epic Games VFX supervisor Pat Tubach, who said he also worked on the Pirates movies, fired back. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs inaccurate for anyone in the industry to claim that one tool is to blame for some erroneously perceived issues with the state of VFX and CGI,‚Äù Tubach said in a statement to VGC. ‚ÄúUnreal Engine is primarily used for pre-visualization, virtual production, and in some cases final pixels. I can guarantee that the artists working on big blockbuster VFX films like Pirates of the Caribbean 10-15 years ago could only dream about having a tool as powerful as Unreal Engine on their desks to help them get the job done. And I should know‚ÄìI was one of them.‚Äù

ICYMI:

  • Stop doomscrolling and go play Forza Horizon 5
  • One analysis firm predicts the Switch 2 is about to go up in price
  • The new Life Is Strange is coming sooner than expected with some unexpected story choices

item.title: This Is The Worst Part Of Borderlands 4
item.content:encoded:
Despite the performance issues, annoying jokes, and bugs, I‚Äôm still playing and enjoying Borderlands 4. I‚Äôm currently working on my second full playthrough with my wife, who is also a big Borderlands fan, and we‚Äôre having a great time. Mostly. Everything is going fine right up until we encounter another damn loot capsule. These things are the worst part of the game and are so bad that they truly baffle me.

As you explore the open world of Borderlands 4, you‚Äôll find side activities and quests to complete. Some of these are elaborate, but other stuff is as simple as killing a specific target or activating a safehouse. One of these supposedly simple and fun little side activities involves Loot Capsules. These are small pods that you can stumble upon and then have to carry back to the nearest safehouse to unlock. Doing so opens the capsule, and you get some loot. Sounds fine, right? Wrong!

In Borderlands 4, Gearbox created a new mechanic that lets you pick up objects while fighting. This is used in various ways in the looter shooter, and most of the time, it is a nice way to spice up a combat encounter or make solving a puzzle just a bit more interesting. But when you hold something in Borderlands 4, you can‚Äôt mantle or climb up a ladder, drive your hover bike, aim down your sights, throw grenades, or fast travel with that object. It greatly limits your toolbox, and that‚Äôs fine when it‚Äôs used sparingly as a momentary wrinkle you have to contend with.

Yet that isn‚Äôt the case with Loot Capsules, which sometimes require you to walk a very long distance back to the ‚Äúclosest‚Äù HQ to get your reward. And you have to walk it. You can‚Äôt use your cool bike. You just run back on foot, unable to take most shortcuts because you can‚Äôt even use your sick grapple hook when holding an item. It is so fucking tedious. If you get attacked by enemies and have to fight your way out, you‚Äôd better hope that nothing happens that dislodges that capsule from your hand, or you could be searching around desperately for it in a moment. Has this happened to me? Yes, why do you think I‚Äôm writing this blog? And when you finally get to your HQ, you might have to solve some platforming puzzle that even involves tossing the damn loot pod across gaps. If it lands in an area you can‚Äôt enter, like a bottomless gorge that kills you, then it respawns back where you found it. Congratulations, you get to do it all over again.

Oh, and every time you pick it up, Claptrap starts talking. Every. Single. Time. Sometimes, he‚Äôll talk over himself. And there are only so many lines. And they go on and on. I don‚Äôt even hate Claptrap like a lot of people do, but I quickly reached my breaking point after just a few capsules.

These damn capsules annoy me so much, and I deal with them so often that I‚Äôve started to overthink how they even work. In a sci-fi universe that lets me digitize dozens of guns and store them on my person easily, why the fuck can‚Äôt I just store the capsule, too? Why must I lug it back? Why can‚Äôt I collect it like all the various shields, guns, and other loot I stuff into my digital trousers with no issue? Who thought this was fun? I‚Äôd love to chat with them because I‚Äôm genuinely curious how this was left in the game. Truly, it baffles me.

Here‚Äôs the funniest part about all of this: I‚Äôd be fine with the bullshit and the capsules if the reward was worth it. In my experience, this is never the case. I‚Äôve opened close to two dozen of these things or more while playing alone and with friends. I‚Äôve never gotten a single legendary weapon. Never. It‚Äôs usually the same crappy loot you often find in random chests, which don‚Äôt require a tenth of the effort to open. I‚Äôve talked to friends about it and they‚Äôve reported the same thing: Worthless loot that you trash the second you see it.

At this point, I‚Äôve started to ignore them when playing Borderlands 4 alone. And when I do pick one up, I just gnash my teeth the whole time as I hear the same damn Claptrap line again. At least I enjoy the rest of the game. Mostly.

item.title: How A Headline Gets Written At Kotaku: Battlefield 6 Edition
item.content:encoded:
Consider this the first in a new series of sporadic posts attempting to demystify what goes on at Kotaku, a website about games but also lots of other stuff. We publish many stories here, sometimes well over a dozen throughout the course of a day. Maybe even a hundred by the end of any given week. Likely the first thing you see on any one of those stories is the headline. How do we come up with those?

Well, in the case of a recent news post about new content coming to Battlefield 6, it went something like this. Staff writer Zack Zwiezen, our resident anti-Pax Armata expert, filed an article summarizing new details on what‚Äôs coming to the shooter in season 2 and beyond. It had the working headline ‚ÄúBattlefield 6 Devs Announce A Classic, Big Map Is Returning And Share Season Two Details.‚Äù Accurate, informative, helpful.

But I spilled my soup during lunch and was feeling a bit cranky. The gaming press, myself included, has a tendency to overuse boring phrases like ‚Äúannounces,‚Äù reveals,‚Äù and ‚Äúshows off‚Äù to convey that a new thing has happened. I pushed for something that sounded different and offered a couple of alternatives. Here‚Äôs the conversation in our work Slack that followed:

Ethan Gach: Battlefield 6 Is Giving Fans A Classic Big Map And More In Season 2
Battlefield 6 Hears You And Reveals A Classic, Big Map For Season 2.
wondering if there‚Äôs something more interesting than announces
just say what you want to say about what you think about this

Zack Zwiezen: Battlefield 6 Bringing Back Another Classic Map And Its A Big One

Ethan Gach: Battlefield 6 Season 2 Brings Back A Classic Map But Will It Be Big Enough?

Zack Zwiezen: Well that‚Äôs the catch. It won‚Äôt be in season 2
they have other maps for season 2
this is likely 3

Ethan Gach: lol why aren‚Äôt they revealing season 2 maps?
that seems like a bad sign for big maps in season 2

Zack Zwiezen: They revealed a season 2 map and teased this OTHER one

Ethan Gach: is it big?

Zack Zwiezen: Bigish
lol
hence why I think they are teasing this OTHER map

Ethan Gach: that seems more the story

Zack Zwiezen: It‚Äôs something I talk about in the post, yeah
can try to build a hed around it

Ethan Gach: wait so the map is confirmed not for season 2?
or they just won‚Äôt say

Zack Zwiezen: It will be in a future season

Carolyn Petit: yeah they want to appease the people pounding the tables and chanting BIG MAP! BIG MAP! by saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôve got a big map coming soon, we promise!‚Äù

Ethan Gach: Battlefield 6 Will Bring Back A Classic Big Map But Not For Season 2

Zack Zwiezen: That works
Battlefield 6 Really Wants You All To Know Big Maps Are Coming, Okay? lol

Ethan Gach: As long as it‚Äôs still accurate that seems like the story to me

Zack Zwiezen: Yeah your hed is accurate

Ethan Gach: Battlefield 6 To Concerned Nation: Big Maps Are Coming‚Ä¶Eventually

Zack Zwiezen: Battlefield 6 Dev Spreads Out Arms Real Wide On Stage And Receives 20 Minutes Of Standing Applause
anyway, posting with your hed

So there you have it. A perfect headline? No. Better than ‚ÄúBattlefield 6 Devs Announce A Classic, Big Map Is Returning And Share Season Two Details?‚Äù Maybe! On the site currently? Yes. And that‚Äôs how it got there.
